instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ,  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B  , Green Light , No Fan Spin
threads.message:
I have an A1644 , <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B board I have been working on. I'll admit , I am not the best at reading schematics , but am trying to learn so please bear with me lol. 

Visual inspection of the board showed corrosion on <RESISTOR>R7564</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7564</CAPACITOR> . After looking futher both traces coming from <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> to <RESISTOR>R7564</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7564</CAPACITOR> were burnt in 2. Repaired both traces. I have short to ground on both 5v and 3.3v lines so I did remove <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> to see if it may be the cause of the short but it's still present with it removed. 
Below are my power rail measurements. 

I'm not really sure where to go from here so hoping someone could point me in the right direction. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> 16.7v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 16.7v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> cycles between 3.8-5v with <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> attached / 1.2v with it removed - no short to ground
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> 0v - short to ground
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 0v - short to ground
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0v with <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> attached / .6v with it removed -- short to grd

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ,  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B  , Green Light , No Fan Spin
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Don't do again the same mistake.
NEVER ever apply power on the board without <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> (or other similar chip) disconnected.
High-side MOSFETs remain with Gate floating (on air); a good reason to get burnt.

Bad connections on R/<CAPACITOR>C7564</CAPACITOR> burnt <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>.
Applying power without <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> burnt <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> too.
Rebuild traces, and change the burnt components.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ,  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B  , Green Light , No Fan Spin
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 96486, member: 682"]
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Don't do again the same mistake.
NEVER ever apply power on the board without <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> (or other similar chip) disconnected.
High-side MOSFETs remain with Gate floating (on air); a good reason to get burnt.

Bad connections on R/<CAPACITOR>C7564</CAPACITOR> burnt <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>.
Applying power without <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> burnt <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> too.
Rebuild traces, and change the burnt components.
[/QUOTE]


Thank you for the reply. Just so I make sure I'm hearing this right , replace both q7520and <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>? If so could you explain what led you to that? I'm trying to get a better understanding of how all this works together . Thanks

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ,  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B  , Green Light , No Fan Spin
threads.message:
"could you explain what led you to that?
..........................
"Bad connections on R/<CAPACITOR>C7564</CAPACITOR> burnt <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>.
 Applying power without <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> burnt <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> too."

You may also need to replace <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> (recommended).

Write directly into reply box (below the last post), instead of clicking Reply button.
No need to quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
Please, maintain forum aesthetic...
